title: Probability Theory in Machine Learning, Deep Learning, and Artificial Intelligence
summary: This document provides definitions, axioms, and corollaries of probability theory, which forms the foundation for machine learning, deep learning, and artificial intelligence. It covers key concepts such as sample space, event, probability axioms, conditioning, and Bayes' rule. The document also includes examples like the discrete uniform law.
key_concepts: A sample space is the set of all possible outcomes, where its elements must be mutually exclusive, collectively exhaustive and at the right granularity.
An event is a subset of the sample space. Probability is assigned to events.
Probability models and axioms define how probabilities are assigned to events and satisfy certain rules.
The discrete uniform law assumes a finite set with equally likely elements, and provides an example for calculating probability of a specific event.
Conditioning and Bayes' rule help in understanding the relationship between events and their probabilities given some conditions.

title: EU AI Act: Codifying Ethics Guidelines for Trustworthy AI
summary: The EU AI Act aims to remove prohibited AI systems from the European market by a deadline of February 2, 2025. The document defines AI as a machine-based system designed to operate with varying levels of autonomy that can influence physical or virtual environments. It proposes a risk-based approach to AI regulation, categorizing AI into unacceptable, high, 'transparency', minimal or no risk, and permitted subject to compliance or information/transparency obligations. The act encourages voluntary codes of conduct for permitted AI with no restrictions.
key_concepts: The EU AI Act aims to remove prohibited AI systems from the European market by a deadline of February 2, 2025.
AI is defined as a machine-based system designed to operate with varying levels of autonomy that can influence physical or virtual environments.

A risk-based approach to AI regulation is proposed, categorizing AI into unacceptable, high, 'transparency', minimal or no risk, and permitted subject to compliance or information/transparency obligations.
The act encourages voluntary codes of conduct for permitted AI with no restrictions.
The document was published by the European Union and Stanford University.
content_preview: EU AI Act: Removing Prohibited AI Systems  From EU Market

title: Data science interview Q&A
summary: This document provides a comprehensive question and answer format for common statistics-related questions in data science interviews. Topics covered include the Central Limit Theorem, sampling methods, Type I vs Type II errors, Linear Regression with explanations of P-value, Coefficient, R-squared value, assumptions required for Linear Regression, Statistical Interaction, Selection Bias, and examples of non-Gaussian distributions.
key_concepts: The Central Limit Theorem is a fundamental theorem in statistics that states that the distribution of the mean of a large number of independent, identically distributed random variables will be approximately normally distributed.

Sampling refers to the process of selecting a subset (a sample) from a larger population for statistical analysis. Common sampling methods include simple random sampling, stratified sampling, cluster sampling, and systematic sampling.
Type I error (false positive) occurs when we incorrectly reject a true null hypothesis, while Type II error (false negative) occurs when we fail to reject a false null hypothesis.

Linear Regression is a statistical model used to analyze the linear relationship between two continuous variables. The P-value indicates the probability that the observed relationship could have occurred by chance, the Coefficient represents the strength and direction of the relationship, and R-squared value measures the proportion of variance in the dependent variable that can be explained by the independent variable.
Statistical Interaction refers to a situation where the effect of one independent variable on the dependent variable depends on the level of another independent variable.
content_preview: Document: Data science interview Q&A

title: Tokenization and LoRa in LLM
summary: This document discusses the concepts of tokenization and LoRa (Low-Rank Adaptation) as techniques for optimizing Large Language Models (LLMs). Tokenization is explained as the process of splitting text into smaller units, improving efficiency and performance. LoRa is a parameter-efficient fine-tuning method that reduces memory usage without compromising performance in Natural Language Processing tasks by adding new trainable parameters to modify a model's behavior without increasing its overall size.
key_concepts: Tokenization is the process of splitting text into smaller units called tokens, which can be words, subwords, or even characters. This step is crucial because LLMs do not understand raw text directly.
LoRa (Low-Rank Adaptation) is a parameter-efficient fine-tuning method that introduces new trainable parameters to modify a model's behavior without increasing its overall size.
Effective tokenization allows models to handle various languages, manage rare words, and reduce the vocabulary size, which improves both efficiency and performance.
LoRa works by adding low-rank matrix adaptations to the model's existing parameters, reducing the memory overhead typically associated with training large models.
LoRa maintains the original parameter count, making it possible to train large models on limited resources.
content_preview: TOPTOPTOP 50 LLM 50 LLM 50 LLM

summary: This document explores the capabilities, scaling properties, and limitations of Large Reasoning Models (LRMs) through controllable puzzle environments. The study reveals that LRMs experience a complete accuracy collapse beyond certain complexities and exhibit a counter-intuitive scaling limit where their reasoning effort increases with problem complexity up to a point, then declines despite the complexity reduction. The work aims to provide insights into the reasoning traces’ structure and quality.
key_concepts: This work investigates the gaps in understanding the fundamental capabilities, scaling properties, and limitations of Large Reasoning Models (LRMs).
The study uses controllable puzzle environments that allow precise manipulation of compositional complexity while maintaining consistent logical structures.
The analysis focuses on not only final answers but also the internal reasoning traces, offering insights into how LRMs ‘think’.
Through extensive experimentation across diverse puzzles, it is shown that frontier LRMs face a complete accuracy collapse beyond certain complexities.
The work reveals an unexpected scaling limit: their reasoning effort increases with problem complexity up to a point, then declines despite the complexity reduction.
content_preview: Recent generations of frontier language models have introduced Large Reasoning Models (LRMs) that generate detailed thinking processes before providing answers.

The notes also discuss concepts like overfitting and regularization.
key_concepts: These notes cover the fundamentals of Machine Learning, a field that focuses on creating algorithms capable of learning from and making decisions based on data.
Linear Regression is a statistical method used to model the relationship between a dependent variable and one or more independent variables.
Nonlinear Regression extends Linear Regression by allowing for relationships between variables that are not linear.
Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) are computational models inspired by biological neural networks, designed to recognize patterns in data.
K-Nearest Neighbors is a simple machine learning algorithm used for classification and regression tasks.

summary: This document is a draft of 'Machine Learning Yearning', a deeplearning.ai project by Andrew Ng. key_concepts: The importance of having development and test sets that come from the same distribution for effective machine learning implementation.
The role of a single-number evaluation metric in optimizing machine learning models.
The concept of 'optimizing and satisficing metrics' to speed up iterations.
The significance of error analysis in evaluating ideas and improving machine learning models.
The tradeoff between bias and variance, and techniques for reducing avoidable bias.

title: Machine Learning Methods for Malware Detection
summary: This document discusses the application of machine learning in malware detection, focusing on concepts such as unsupervised and supervised learning, deep learning, false positive rates, and adaptability to counteractions. The paper also covers specific applications in cybersecurity, including pre-execution detection with similarity hashing, two-stage pre-execution detection, deep learning against rare attacks, and post-execution behavior detection. It also touches upon the use of machine learning in clustering incoming data streams and distillation for updates.
key_concepts: The paper discusses the extensive experience of using machine learning to build advanced protection against malware for customers.
Unsupervised and supervised learning, deep learning are the main machine learning concepts discussed in this document.
Trained models in malware detection require large representative datasets, low false positive rates, interpretability, and quick adaptability to counteractions.
The paper presents Kaspersky's application of machine learning for detecting new malware in pre-execution with similarity hashing and two-stage pre-execution detection on users’ computers.

Deep learning is used against rare attacks and in post-execution behavior detection, while also discussing its applications in the infrastructure such as clustering incoming data streams and distillation for updates.

title: Mathematics Theory of Deep Learning
summary: This document delves into the mathematical foundations of deep learning, exploring topics such as feedforward neural networks, universal approximation, and splines. The authors, Philipp Petersen and Jakob Zech, provide a comprehensive overview of these concepts, including their formal definitions, activation functions, and theoretical underpinnings. The work also discusses the universal approximation theorem and Kolmogorov’s superposition theorem in the context of deep learning. Practical applications and use cases are not extensively covered in this book.
key_concepts: This document presents the mathematical theory behind deep learning, providing a formal definition of feedforward neural networks and discussing their size and activation functions.
The authors introduce the concept of universal approximation, demonstrating how deep learning models can approximate any continuous function with sufficient capacity.
The work also discusses B-splines and smooth functions, which are essential in understanding the mathematical foundations of deep learning.
The document explains the universal approximation theorem and Kolmogorov’s superposition theorem, shedding light on the theoretical underpinnings of deep learning.

While this book does not extensively cover practical applications and use cases, it serves as a valuable resource for researchers and practitioners seeking to understand the mathematical foundations of deep learning.

title: Oversight Structures for Agentic AI in Public-Sector Organizations
summary: This document explores the challenges posed by agentic AI systems to traditional public sector oversight mechanisms. It identifies five essential governance dimensions for responsible deployment: cross-departmental implementation, comprehensive evaluation, enhanced security protocols, operational visibility, and systematic auditing. The study evaluates the capacity of existing oversight structures using a mixed-methods approach, consisting of a literature review and interviews with civil servants in AI-related roles. Findings suggest that agent oversight poses intensified versions of three existing governance challenges: continuous oversight, deeper integration of governance and operation...
key_concepts: The introduction of agentic AI systems intensifies existing challenges to traditional public sector oversight mechanisms.

Five governance dimensions essential for responsible agent deployment are identified: cross-departmental implementation, comprehensive evaluation, enhanced security protocols, operational visibility, and systematic auditing.
Existing oversight structures are evaluated via a mixed-methods approach consisting of a literature review and interviews with civil servants in AI-related roles.

Agent oversight poses intensified versions of three existing governance challenges: continuous oversight, deeper integration of governance and operational capabilities, and interdepartmental coordination.
Proposed approaches adapt institutional structures and design agent oversight compatible with public sector constraints.
content_preview: arXiv:2506.04836v1  [cs.CY]  5 Jun 2025Oversight Structures for Agentic AI in Public-Sector Organizations

title: Overview of Artificial Intelligence Regulation
summary: This document presents an overview of artificial intelligence (AI) regulation in Switzerland, addressing the rapid development of AI, its opportunities, and the new legal challenges it poses. The report discusses international regulations such as the Council of Europe's AI Convention and the EU's AI Act, and highlights the need for an overarching AI-specific legislation in Switzerland due to the current framework's inadequacy. The Federal Council has commissioned this overview to decide on the future Swiss regulatory approach in the field of AI.
key_concepts: AI has rapidly developed and reached the general public with applications like ChatGPT, offering great opportunities for Switzerland as a business and innovation location.
New legal challenges arise regarding transparency and traceability of AI-based decisions.
International regulations such as the Council of Europe's AI Convention and the EU's AI Act have been drawn up, but there is no overarching AI-specific legislation in Switzerland.
The Federal Council has made AI a priority in its 2023-2027 legislative plan, calling for a fundamental decision on the future Swiss regulatory approach in the field of AI.
This overview serves as a basis for the Federal Council to decide on the future Swiss regulatory approach in the field of AI.
content_preview: BAKOM -D-A5D93401/201   Federal  Department  of the Environment,  Transport,Energy   Federal Office of Communications OFCOM   12 February 2025   Overview of artificial intelligence regulation Report to the Federal Council

title: A Closer Look at the Existing Risks of Generative AI
summary: This document presents a comprehensive analysis of real-world incidents related to Generative AI, mapping the causes, effects, and stakeholders involved. title: Large Language Models and Emotional Intelligence Tests
authors: Katja Schlegel1,2, Nils R. Sommere1& Marcello Mortillaro3
summary: This research investigates the emotional intelligence capabilities of large language models (LLMs) by examining their performance on standard emotional intelligence tests. The study found that LLMs, specifically ChatGPT-4, outperformed humans with an average accuracy of 81%, compared to human averages of 56% in original validation studies. The research also shows that LLMs can generate new test items for emotional intelligence tests, which were administered to human participants across five studies.
key_concepts: LLMs demonstrate expertise in diverse domains but their emotional intelligence is uncertain.
Research examines LLMs' ability to solve and generate performance-based emotional intelligence tests.
ChatGPT-4 outperformed humans on five standard emotional intelligence tests with an average accuracy of 81%.
ChatGPT-4 generated new test items for each emotional intelligence test, which were administered to human participants across five studies.

Original and ChatGPT-generated tests demonstrated statistically equivalent test difficulty but differences in other factors such as clarity, realism, diversity, internal consistency, correlations with vocabulary and external ability emotional intelligence tests were smaller than Cohen's d ± 0.25.
content_preview: Large language models are pro ﬁcient in solving and creating emotional intelligence tests

title: Simulating Human Behavior with AI Agents
summary: This document discusses an AI agent architecture capable of simulating human attitudes and behaviors, using generative agents that mimic individuals based on LLM paired with in-depth interview transcripts. The accuracy of these agents was tested against real participants' responses to major social science surveys and experiments, achieving 85% accuracy compared to the individuals' own answers two weeks later on the General Social Survey. The document emphasizes the need for policymakers and researchers to collaborate in ensuring appropriate monitoring and consent mechanisms are implemented to mitigate risks while harnessing potential benefits.
key_concepts: The AI agent architecture can simulate real people in ways far more complex than traditional approaches.
Generative agents were created to simulate 1,000 individuals, each using an LLM paired with an in-depth interview transcript of the individual.
The agents' responses were evaluated against corresponding participants' responses on major social science surveys and experiments.
The generative agents replicated real participants’ responses 85% as accurately as the individuals replicated their own answers two weeks later on the General Social Survey.
Policymakers and researchers must work together to ensure appropriate monitoring and consent mechanisms are used for these generative agents.
content_preview: AI agents have been gaining widespread attention...

title: The Artificial Intelligence Diffusion Framework
summary: This document discusses the Artificial Intelligence Diffusion Framework, exploring its potential impact on creating a U.S.-led global AI ecosystem. The paper is a policy perspective by Lennart Heim, released in January 2025 and updated in February 2025. It was published by RAND, a nonprofit research organization dedicated to improving public policy. The document delves into the implications of export controls on AI development and discusses the framework's potential impact on global AI ecosystems.
key_concepts: The Artificial Intelligence Diffusion Framework is a proposed framework that outlines the stages and factors influencing the adoption and diffusion of AI technologies across different regions.
The document examines whether export controls can lead to a U.S.-led global AI ecosystem, considering the potential economic and strategic implications.
The paper presents expert insights on this timely policy issue, offering perspectives on the potential outcomes and challenges associated with such a scenario.
The study is based on RAND's mission to improve policy and decision-making through research and analysis, upholding quality, objectivity, and integrity in its work.
The document provides insights into the potential practical implications of this framework for global AI development and governance.
content_preview: This document was initially released in January 2025; it was updated in February 2025 with minor proofread corrections and content slightly reorganized for ease of reading.

title: The Rise of Self-Driving AI
summary: This document explores how autonomous AI is transforming the way we work across various industries. It discusses the evolution from assisted to autonomous AI, its implications for industries, organizations, and the workforce, and provides examples of its application in finance and healthcare. The document also delves into the history of AI autonomy, tracing its roots from rule-based systems to adaptive agents.
key_concepts: The rise of autonomous AI marks a fundamental shift from machines following human commands to independently solving complex problems.
Autonomous agents are now capable of making decisions and taking actions independently, ushering in an era of unprecedented efficiency and innovation.

Breakthroughs in machine learning (ML) and reinforcement learning have enabled the development of adaptive agents that can analyze data, learn from interactions, and autonomously solve complex problems.
The evolution from assisted to autonomous AI has profound implications for industries, organizations, and the workforce.

Examples of autonomous AI in action include financial services firms using AI agents to monitor market trends, execute trades, and mitigate risks, as well as healthcare providers relying on AI agents for diagnosing illnesses, recommending treatments, and scheduling follow-ups.

title: The effect of ChatGPT on students’ learning performance
summary: This document presents a meta-analysis study assessing the effectiveness of ChatGPT in improving students' learning performance, learning perception, and higher-order thinking. The results indicate a large positive impact (g=0.867) on learning performance, a moderately positive impact (g=0.456) on learning perception, and fostering higher-order thinking (g=0.457). The study suggests providing appropriate learning scaffolds or educational frameworks when using ChatGPT to develop students' higher-order thinking.
key_concepts: ChatGPT, as a new type of artificial intelligence, is being widely used in learning but academic consensus regarding its effectiveness remains elusive.
The study aimed to assess the effectiveness of ChatGPT through a meta-analysis of 51 research studies published between November 2022 and February 2025.

The results indicate that ChatGPT has a large positive impact on improving learning performance (g=0.867) and a moderately positive impact on enhancing learning perception (g=0.456) and fostering higher-order thinking (g=0.457).
The impact of ChatGPT was moderated by type of course, learning model, duration, and its role.
The study suggests providing appropriate learning scaffolds or educational frameworks when using ChatGPT to develop students' higher-order thinking.

The document serves as a valuable resource for developers looking to improve their coding skills.
key_concepts: The Two Sum problem involves finding two numbers in an array that add up to a given target value.
The Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters problem requires finding the longest substring within a string without any repeating characters.
The Median of Two Sorted Arrays problem asks for the median when presented with two sorted arrays of different lengths.
The Longest Palindromic Substring problem involves finding the longest palindrome within a given string.
The ZigZag Conversion problem deals with converting a string into a zigzag pattern.

title: Two types of AI existential risk
summary: This paper explores two perspectives on existential risks from AI: decisive and accumulative. The conventional view focuses on abrupt, dire events caused by advanced AI systems, while the accumulative hypothesis suggests a gradual accumulation of AI-induced threats that could lead to systemic erosion and societal collapse over time.
key_concepts: The conventional discourse on existential risks from AI typically focuses on abrupt, dire events caused by advanced AI systems.
The accumulative hypothesis suggests a gradual accumulation of AI-induced threats that could lead to systemic erosion and societal collapse over time.
This involves a gradual accumulation of AI risks that slowly undermine systematic and societal resilience until a triggering event results in irreversible collapse.
The paper contrasts the conventional decisive AI x-risk hypothesis with what I call an accumulative AI x-risk hypothesis.
content_preview: This paper contrasts the conventional decisive AI existential risk with an accumulative AI existential risk.

title: Convolutional Neural Networks Cheatsheet
summary: This document provides an overview of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), a type of neural network commonly used in deep learning. It explains the architecture, layers (convolution, pooling, and fully connected), their hyperparameters, and their purposes. The convolution layer uses filters to perform convolution operations on the input, while the pooling layer downsamples the feature map for spatial invariance. Max and average pooling are discussed as special kinds of pooling. The fully connected layer operates on a flattened input.
key_concepts: Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) are a specific type of neural networks with layers including the convolution layer, pooling layer, and fully connected layer.
The convolution layer uses filters to perform convolution operations on the input, with hyperparameters such as filter size and stride.
The pooling layer is a downsampling operation applied after a convolution layer for spatial invariance, using max or average pooling.
Max pooling selects the maximum value of the current view, while average pooling averages the values of the current view.
The fully connected layer operates on a flattened input.
